title: The opportunity society that spurns class warfare
text:
Just two weeks after a federal election in which Australians rejected a redistributionist dirge against the big end of town, the Financial Review Rich List celebrates this opportunity society in which people can get ahead, and in doing so create wealth, jobs and more prosperous futures for many others.

Damned as one percenters, less than one in seven of the Rich Listers come from inherited wealth. Australia’s rich are distinguished from the US and Europe for their lack of aristocrats, old-time monopolists and robber barons. Their number includes the most extraordinary rags-to-riches Australian immigrant success stories.

The big trend in this year's list of Australia’s 200 wealthiest people – which required a minimum fortune of $472 million to qualify – has been the continued rise of tech entrepreneurs, up to 14 from 10 last year. These new entrepreneurs have harnessed the internet to overcome the traditional tyranny of distance to build global markets, quickly. These are companies such as Mike Cannon-Brookes’ and Scott Farquhar’s Atlassian, Richard White’s WiseTech and Sweat, the global fitness app created by personal trainers Tobias Pearce and Kayla Itsines in Adelaide. The Atlassian founders are from middle-class families and started their company on a credit card. Now they own the two old Fairfax family mansions, purchased in the year that Fairfax ceased to exist as a standalone company.

The top one and two on the list, Anthony Pratt and Gina Rinehart, have used their inherited wealth to build even bigger companies, massively increasing their wealth while creating jobs and prosperity for many others. According to Mr Pratt, Pratt Industries and Visy have been spurred along by the Donald Trump tax cuts and instant expensing of new investment. Pratt Industries is creating new employment across the Trump-voting American midwest. Gina Rinehart could have lived her life as a royalties heiress: instead she built her own massive Roy Hill Mine in the Pilbara.

The Trump stimulus injected into the global economy has been one notable driver of global international growth. But an iron ore price that jumped to $US108 a tonne this week shows how important China's blast furnaces remain to Australian prosperity, including iron ore entrepreneurs Ms Rinehart and Andrew Forrest. Yet the names that fell off this year’s Rich List also show the risks present in a China opaque markets, politics and regulatory regimes. Marcus Blackmore, Jane Cameron and Bruce Neill – all with big exposures to China’s consumer markets that use grey channels and daigou shoppers to get their goods into China – fell off the list, highlighting the risks associated with having many eggs in one basket.
